results.title: The Swingle singers
results.brief_description: A group of eight singers from Paris under the direction of American Ward Swingle, sing music by Bach in jazz idiom, accompanied by two musicians on bass and drums.

results.title: The Swineherd (K)
results.creator_credit: Paul Hammerich, Weston Woods Studios and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: A spoiled princess scorns the love of a worthy prince yet will kiss a swineherd a hundred times for a silly musical toy. An adaptation of the Hans Christian Andersen story that uses original illustrations from the book by Bjorn Wiinblad. Interesting animation by Gene Deitch with touches of irony in narration. Suitable for lower and middle primary levels.

results.title: The Swindle = Il Bidone
results.brief_description: Three small time confidence tricksters unite to try and get money by robing the poor. “Il Bidone” is crime-doesn’t-pay film with a realistic starkness only Fellini could instigate. Strong performances play out in a harsh setting and with dire consequences for the main protagonist Augusto (Broderick Crawford) as he tries to help his estranged daughter with money to attend college but ends up betrayed by those who, like him, are swindlers up to no good. The second film in Fellini’s so called trilogy about loneliness (which include “La Strada” and “Le Notti di Cabiria”). Cast includes: Giulietta Masina, Richard Basehart, Franco Fabrizi.

results.title: The Swimming Pool
results.brief_description: Our hero looks forward with great anticipation to enjoying his new swimming pool, only to be thwarted at every turn. The pool becomes a magnet for trespassing children, sailboats, a spaceship complete with astronauts, a thirsty elephant and a ten-car pile-up. In utter frustration he gives up, fills in the pool and plants a tree-only to be hit on the head by a falling apple

results.title: The Swimming hole
results.creator_credit: King Screen Productions and Skeets McGrew
results.brief_description: Seemingly a story of a teenage farmboy who has come to the river to fish, this wordlessfilm takes on a deeper meaning, opening out into an allegory on humans and their relationship to the environment. It makes the point that we must understand the delicate natural balance before attempting to interfere with it.

results.title: The Swimmer
results.creator_credit: Frank Bagnall, Malcolm Smith and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Man and His Sport”.
Presents aspects of the sport of swimming in Australia, in particular the physical and psychological preparation of champion Australian swimmers for the 1970 Commonwealth Games. Coaches Forbes Carlile and Don Talbot and swimmers Karen Moras and Diana Rickard are seen at work.

results.title: The Sweet hereafter
results.creator_credit: Alliance, Ego Film Arts, Camelia Frieberg and Atom Egoyan
results.brief_description: In a small mountain town a lawyer (Ian Holm) arrives to argue that the parents of children killed in a horrific bus accident should claim compensation for the tragedy. The lawyer himself is dealing with his own daughter’s heroin addiction and his inability to assist her. As this wonderful and intelligent film unfolds, we as an audience are led to explore issues of familial and personal responsibility, in particular the difficult searing question of what it means to be parent to a child. We are also asked to question our culture’s increasing fear and terror of accident and death. Filmed in glorious Canadian wilderness in the middle of heavy winter, “The Sweet Hereafter” is a masterful film: script, cinematography and acting are nearly faultless. Egoyan has consistently been proving himself to be one of the most challenging, exciting and experimental of film directors working in cinema since the 1980s. This assured classical film is both a departure and a culmination of his work: his films have all explored the alienation and loneliness of our contemporary world and our increasing estrangement from family and each other. It is no exaggeration to call this film one of the most emotionally and intellectually profound films of modern cinema. Based on a novel by Russell Banks. Cast includes Sarah Polley, Maury Chaykin, Peter Donaldson, Bruce Greenwood and Arsinee Khanjian.

results.title: The Swedish fokus
results.creator_credit: John Miller, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: A film study of the Fokus flats at Taby, Stockholm, it examines how far these specially-designed apartments have liberated handicapped people from their physical constraints. Peter Large, who has himself been disabled by a polio attack, talks to the Swedish tenants about their living environment and opportunities.
